title: Synthesis and structural characterisation of an yttrium-alkyl-alkylidene

references.title: NBO 5.0.; Theoretical Chemistry Institute,
references.raw: Morales, Weinhold, F. NBO 5.0.; Theoretical Chemistry Institute, University of Wisconsin: Madison 2001.

references.title: Supplementary Material (ESI) for Chemical Communications This journal is (c) The Royal Society of Chemistry
references.raw: Supplementary Material (ESI) for Chemical Communications This journal is (c) The Royal Society of Chemistry 2008

abstract: The first structurally authenticated yttrium-alkyl-alkylidene is reported; structural, spectroscopic, and theoretical analyses show that whilst the yttrium-alkylidene bond is short, it possesses a bond order less than one and is comparable to the Y-C-alkyl single bond within the same molecule

Synthesis and structural characterisation of an yttrium-alkyl-alkylidene</dc:title><dc:creator>
Arnold, Polly</dc:creator><dc:creator>

metal-carbon bonds; x-ray structures; nobel lecture; olefin-metathesis; transition-metal; carbene complex; reactivity; dft; bis(phosphinimino)methanides; stabilization</dc:subject><dc:description>
The first structurally authenticated yttrium-alkyl-alkylidene is reported; structural, spectroscopic, and theoretical analyses show that whilst the yttrium-alkylidene bond is short, it possesses a bond order less than one and is comparable to the Y-C-alkyl single bond within the same molecule.</dc:description><dc:date>

fullText:
Supplementary Material (ESI) for Chemical Communications 
This journal is (c) The Royal Society of Chemistry 2008 
 
Supplementary Information 
 
Synthesis and Structural Characterisation of an Yttrium-Alkyl-Alkylidene 
 
Stephen T. Liddle,* Jonathan McMaster, Jennifer C. Green, Polly L. Arnold 
 
Synthesis and Spectroscopy  
 
All manipulations were carried out under anaerobic and anhydrous conditions. Toluene (30 ml) was 
added to a pre-cooled (–78 °C) mixture of [Y(CH2SiMe3)3(THF)2] (1.72 g, 3.48 mmol) and 
H2C(PPh2NSiMe3)2 (1.85 g, 3.48 mmol) and the mixture was allowed to slowly warm to room 
temperature with stirring over 18 hours. Volatiles were removed in vacuo and the resulting pale 
yellow solid was recrystallised from hexane/toluene (5:2 ml) to afford 1 as colourless crystals. 
Yield: 1.21 g, 43%. Anal. Calcd for C39H57N2OP2Si3Y: C, 58.19; H, 7.14; N, 3.48. Found: C, 58.07; 
H, 7.09; N, 3.51. 
1H NMR (d6-benzene, 298 K): δ –0.18 (d, 
2JYH = 2.88 Hz, 2H, CH2Si), 0.16 (s, 
18H, NSi(CH3)3), 0.65 (s, 9H, CH2Si(CH3)3), 1.43 (m, 4H, OCH2CH2), 3.93 (m, 4H, OCH2CH2), 
7.12 (m, br, 16H, o- and m-Ar-CH) and 7.81 (m, br, 4H, p-Ar-CH). 
13C{
1H} NMR (d6-benzene, 298 
K): δ 3.78 (NSi(CH3)3), 4.86 (CH2Si(CH3)3), 24.92 (OCH2CH2), 33.17 (d, 
1JYC = 43.90 Hz, CH2Si), 
60.08 (td, 
1JPC = 131.86 Hz, 
1JYC = 4.88 Hz, YCP2), 69.86 (OCH2CH2), 129.14 (Ar-C), 131.36 (Ar-
C) and 139.32 (t, 
1JPC = 50.34 Hz, i-Ar-C). One Ar-C resonance was obscured by the C6D6 solvent 
resonance. 
31P{
1H} NMR (d6-benzene, 298 K): δ 7.30 (d, 
2JYP = 11.53 Hz, NPC). 
 
DFT Calculations 
The calculations were performed using the Amsterdam Density Functional (ADF) suite version 
2006.01.
[1, 2] The restricted relativistic geometry optimization DFT calculations for 1 employed a Supplementary Material (ESI) for Chemical Communications 
This journal is (c) The Royal Society of Chemistry 2008 
 
Slater type orbital (STO) triple-ζ-plus one polarization function basis set from the ZORA/TZP 
database of the ADF suite for all atoms. Frozen core basis sets were used for C (1s), N (1s), O (1s), 
Si (2p), P (2p) and Y (4p). Scalar relativistic (SR) approaches were used within the ZORA 
Hamiltonian for the inclusion of relativistic effects. The local density approximation (LDA) with 
the correlation potential due to Vosko et al was used in all of the DFT calculations.
[3] Gradient 
corrections were performed using the functionals of Becke
[4] and Perdew
[5] (BP). Natural Bond 
Orbital analyses were performed using NBO v5
[6] using the results of DFT calculations in which all 
electron basis sets were used as follows: ZORA/DZ for all H atoms and the C atoms pendant to the 
Si atoms, and ZORA/TZP for all other atoms. We chose this approach because of memory storage 
limitations in NBO v5. The Kohn-Sham orbitals were visualized in MOLEKEL.
[7]  
 
References 
 
[1]  C, Fonseca Guerra, J. G. Snijders, G. te Velde, E. J. Baerends, Theor. Chem. Acc., 1998, 
  99, 391. 
[2]  G. te Velde, F. M. Bickelhaupt, S. J. A. van Gisbergen, C. Fonseca Guerra, E. J. Baerends, J. 
G. Snijders, T. Ziegler, J. Comput. Chem., 2001, 22, 931. 
[3]  S. H. Vosko, L. Wilk, M. Nusair, Can. J. Phys., 1980, 58, 1200. 
[4]  A. D. Becke, Phys. Rev. A, 1988, 38, 3098. 
[5]  J. P. Perdew, Phys. Rev. B, 1986, 33, 8822. 
[6]  E. D. Glendening, J. K. Badenhoop, A. E. Reed, J. E. Carpenter, J. A. Bohmann, C. M. 
Morales, Weinhold, F. NBO 5.0.; Theoretical Chemistry Institute, University of Wisconsin: 
Madison 2001. 
[7]  P. Flükiger, H. P. Lüthi, S. Portmann, J. Weber, MOLEKEL 4.0 Swiss Center for  Scientific 
Computing, Manno (Switzerland), 2000.
